titleStmt.title: Le livre de la vision by Christine de Pizan

note.p: Français 1176, Bibliothéque national de France, Paris. Paris, 1405-1406.
Ivory colored parchment with numerous defects like holes and stains. The vis-à-vis is respected, except for folios 43-46.
(II) + I + 81 + (I) + I. Modern foliation on the top right is accurate.

There are regular light grey ruling marks. There is also evidence of pricking with ten master pricks on every single folio. The pricks were done with different awls (slits, triangular, round). There are two columns with 31, sometimes 32, lines each.

The text is written quite uniformely in dark brown ink, with bright red for the rubrics. The text seems to have been written by one scribe (Hand X) in an exuberant cursive calligraphic script. All his "e" had a slight horn on top, and the letters at the beginning and end of lines had prolonged stems. Some lettes contain phylacteries or cadels as well. Punctuation marks are also used, especially the comma and period, with an overwhelming preference for the former. There are corrections by the hand of X and X' throughout the manuscript.

The ornamental decoration of the manuscript was created by the artist whose style has been identified as "aux brins de fantaisie". The manuscript contains two large foliated initials over a gold leaf background (vignette). In folio 1, the initial I, with red, blue and white foliates, is connected to the gold leaf foliated bar border. Some crosslets are interspersed between the foliage on the border. On folio 25, there is an initial A, with red, blue and white foliates, over a gold leaf and blue background (vignette), with foliate extenders that partially frams the rubric above and the text below on the left margin.
There are many small gold leaf initials at the beginning of each text over alternating backgrounds in either blue or pink.
There is only one miniature decorating this manuscript on folio 1, Christine writing at her desk, created by the Master of l'Epitre Othea.

The manuscript is bound in red Moroccan leather with the royal coat of arms on the covers within three golden filets. The spine contains five nerves decorated with large fleurs de lys surrounded by smaller ones. The title of the work appears as "VISION DE CHRIS" on the spine as well. The last section appears partially covered by the shelfmark "FR 1176". The borders of the covers, thin lines, are embossed in gold.
This manuscript can be dated to the end of 1405 or the beginnings of 1406. This manuscript is the oldest copy of this work that has come down to us.

Provenance: The inside of the top cover contains an inscription written by the hand of one of Charles d'Orleans' librarians that reads "La Vision de Cristine du duc de Berry". It is possible that the volume belonged first to the Jean de Berry (1340-1416), which was then given as a gift to his nephew, Louis d'Orleans, who then gave it to Charles d'Orleans. As with the rest of the library of charles d'Orelans, this manuscript entered the Royal Library with the stamp located on ff. 1 and 81. On folio 1 there are the following old shelfmarks: 944 (Rigault), 705 (Dupuy) and 7394 (Regius).
The manuscript only contains the Livre de la Vision by Christine de Pizan.
*The information given here comes from direct observation and from Ouy, Gilbert, Christine Reno and Inès Villela-Petit. Album Christine de Pizan . Turnhout: Brepols, 2012.
Description by Mónica Ann Walker Vadillo
